column4: that is a really bad statement to make, and your follow-up hardly makes it any better
well, I'm having all sorts of problems with hardy so it might be bad but utterly true.
the fact that you are having problems does not justify claiming that it's "broken" if plenty of people have upgraded or installed it successfully
I really doubt they successfully upgraded on an iBook.
that kind of thing is called FUD and is not welcome here
I've been using Ubuntu since 5.10 and Hardy is the worst I ever ran.
extrapolating your personal bad experience and saying that it's broken is FUD and does not belong here.
but maybe you can tell me why my CPU is constantly on 100% freq even though it is totally idle and everything has been working until the second I upgraded.
I have my own share of problems with hardy. Do I go around and scare people because of it? No, because that is utterly unreasonable behaviour.
sleep and hibernate are broken and there are active bugs in launchpad about this.
any software has bugs. Any major upgrade will contain regressions.
it would be much more unnreasonable to tell him to upgrade.
this is called an LTS release.
then say so. But don't say that hardy is broken, when for plenty of people it clearly isn't.
and I'm not here to complain. All I wanted to know is which component is responsible for frequency scaling in hardy so I can file a bug. pbbuttonsd doesn't seem to do it anymore.
okay. I can see that you are reasonable and have the best intentions. Please be careful with your wording, though.
I have previously filed a freq scaling related bug against the kernel, and it was processed there, so it should be fine if you do the same.
OK. I'll do that, then. Thanks.
